Term.Name: MXF
Term.Definition: The MXF file (defined by SMPTE ST 377) structure provides a means of exchanging metadata using a formal data structure that permits interoperability together with an essence container that can accommodate many different essence formats both compressed and uncompressed and including video streams, individual pictures, sound and essence data (such as sub-titles, VBI data etc.).

Term.Name: OP1a
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 1a: Single Item, Single Package.

Term.Name: OP1b
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 1b: Single Item, Ganged Packages.

Term.Name: OP1c
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 1c: Single Item, Alternate Packages.

Term.Name: OP2a
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 2a: Play-list Items, Single Package.

Term.Name: OP2b
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 2b: Play-list Items, Ganged Packages.

Term.Name: OP2c
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 2c: Play-list Items, Alternate Packages.

Term.Name: OP3a
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 3a: Edit Items, Single Package.

Term.Name: OP3b
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 3b: Edit Items, Ganged Packages.

Term.Name: OP3c
Term.Definition: MXF Operational Pattern 3c: Edit Items, Alternate Packages.

Term.Name: OP Atom
Term.Definition: Specialized Operational Pattern OP-Atom is a simplified operational pattern for the storage and interchange of a single item of essence. Each OP-Atom MXF file contains a single essence stream in a single partition.

Term.Name: AS-01 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 01: Edit metadata interchange using AAF. Includes base set of effects.

Term.Name: AS-02 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 02: Storage of MXF program components to enable versions & inventories, for use in a multi-version, multi-lingual, multi-delivery media environment.

Term.Name: AS-03 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 03: MXF optimized for program delivery intended for direct playout via a video server for example. This is based on a PBS profile for MXF program delivery.

Term.Name: AS-05 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 05: Extends AS-01 with color, text & opacity effects.

Term.Name: AS-07 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 07: A vendor-neutral subset of the MXF file format to use for long-term archiving and preservation of moving image content and associated materials including audio, captions and metadata. Archive and Preservation files may contain a single item, or an entire series of items.

Term.Name: AS-10 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 10: MXF for end-to-end production workflow.

Term.Name: AS-11 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 11: The AMWA AS-11 family of Specifications define constrained media file formats for the delivery of finished media assets to a broadcaster or publisher. Includes Specifications used by broadcasters in the UK (DPP), Nordic countries, Australia and New Zealand.

Term.Name: AS-12 AMWA
Term.Definition: AMWA Application Specification 12: MXF format optimized for the delivery of finished commercials to broadcast stations. AS-12 adds advertising identification metadata to an advertisement contained in an AMWA MXF Application Specification compliant MXF file.

Term.Name: atj
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by the homonimous Robert Jung compression utility
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: bzip2
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by the homonimous compression utility found in Unix distributions
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: compress
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by the homonimous compression utility found in Unix distributions
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: gzip
Term.Definition: Data file compressed acording to IETF RFC 1952: GZIP file format specification version 4.3
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: jar
Term.Definition: type of archive consisting of a Zip archive, as defined by PKWARE, containing a manifest file and potentially signature files, as defined in the Manifest and Signature specification
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: tar
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by the homonimous Unix command without compression option applied. So this is not a compression format, but rather an archive format, as the files in a tar archive are not compressed, just gathered together in one file.The archive file is often called "Tarball", which is a jargon term for a tar archive, suggesting "a bunch of files stuck together in a ball of tar."
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: tar.bzip2
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by tar Unix command with bzip2 compression applied. In this case files are first gathered together in one file, which is than compressed by bzip2.
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: tar.compress
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: tar.gzip
Term.Definition: A type of archive as created by tar Unix command with gzip compression applied. In this case files are first gathered together in one file, which is than compressed by gzip
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML

Term.Name: zip
Term.Definition: A type of archive used for distributing and storing files. Zip files contain one or more files. Usually the files "archived" in a Zip are compressed to save space. Zip files make it easy to group files and make transporting and copying these files faster
Term.ChangeComment: First version after conversion of P/META into XML
